hero.title: What is a Tension Gas Spring?
hero.subtitle: Discover the hidden force that pulls lids, hatches and guards back into place—smoothly, safely and without motors.

freeState.title: 1. Free-state = Rod Retracted
freeState.desc: Unlike normal gas springs, a tension (pull-type) gas spring keeps its rod fully inside when nobody touches it. Gravity or manual force must pull the rod out to open the lid.

assist.title: 2. Self-retracting Assist
assist.desc: When closing, internal compressed gas acts like a “reverse” spring—automatically retracting the rod and helping the lid back down. No extra latch, motor or hand-force required.

specs.title: Key Specifications Customers Ask For
items: Single or double-tube design for different speed/curve behaviour
End-fittings with anti-drop safety pin or wire
Annual volumes 500-5 000 pcs, FOB + door-to-door freight

comparison.title: Single-tube vs. Double-tube
comparison.single: Single: faster retraction, steeper force rise (100 N → ~175 N over stroke).
comparison.double: Double: smoother, more linear curve (100 N → ~150 N) and reduced vibration—perfect when noise or precision matters.

tableSection.title: Traction Spring vs. Pure Damper — Quick Pick
tableSection.note: * Pure Damper Note: A damper provides resistance in one or both directions to prevent slamming, but it does not store energy to return the application to its starting position. You must manually push it back.

action.title: Need a Custom Tension Spring?
action.desc: Send us your required force, stroke and end-fitting drawing. We’ll return a detailed quote with FOB & door-to-door freight within 24 h.
action.catalogLink: Or download our spec sheet → PDF catalog

hero.title: Compression Gas Spring
hero.subtitle: Compression Gas Spring (Gas Strut) - Technical Guide

content.title: Compression Gas Spring
content.definition: (also known as Gas Strut, Gas Spring, Gas Lift, or Support Rod) is an industrial component that uses high-pressure inert gas (typically nitrogen) to provide controlled support, buffering, and lifting force. It's widely used in applications requiring precise, smooth motion control.

coreFunction.title: Core Function
coreFunction.description: Through compressed nitrogen, gas springs provide stable lifting force to assist in opening, supporting, and cushioning heavy components.

items.name: Furniture:
items.value: Flip-up doors, cabinet doors, height-adjustable tables

items.name: Industrial Machinery:
items.value: Equipment enclosures, maintenance covers, safety guards
Specify the use case and required motion.
Record the extended and compressed center-to-center distances.
Calculate the necessary force based on load and geometry.
Select fittings compatible with your mounting points.

subItems.value: Consider special coatings or stainless steel for corrosion resistance.

desc: Our expert team is here to help you configure the perfect solution.

hero.title: Micro Gas Spring Solutions
hero.description: Precision-engineered miniature gas springs for compact spaces—delivering light thrust, short stroke, and silent operation

definition.title: 1. Product Definition
content: Micro Gas Spring, also known as miniature gas spring, micro gas strut, or small gas spring, is a precision product created by proportionally scaling down standard gas springs.

These compact actuators are engineered for applications where space is at a premium and performance cannot be compromised. Whether supporting inspection hatches in medical devices or enabling smooth operation in handheld tools, micro gas springs deliver reliable, whisper-quiet motion control.
definition.quote: The core value lies in meeting the stringent demands of confined spaces for "light thrust, short stroke, and low noise"—making it an irreplaceable precision micro-actuator where traditional mechanical springs or standard gas springs fall short.

specifications.title: 2. Core Dimensions & Force Values
specifications.description: Micro gas springs feature ultra-compact design with refined force options to accommodate diverse miniaturized equipment requirements.

items.spec: 8 mm / 10 mm
items.remark: 10 mm is the market standard, most widely applied.
Rod diameter determines load capacity and structural strength.
Increments of 5 mm provide flexible selection options.
30 / 50 / 80 / 100 N are standard stock configurations.
Applies to 10–100 mm stroke range; ideal for weight-sensitive designs.

performance.title: 3. Performance Indicators
performance.description: While maintaining ultra-compact dimensions, micro gas springs are optimized for performance, with particular emphasis on low noise and extended service life.

items.remark: Ensures quiet operation, meeting precision instrument requirements.
Guaranteed leak-free operation under rated load and stroke.
Standard corrosion resistance; 48 h premium option available.
Precise unlock force control for self-locking variants.

connectors.title: 4. End Connector Types
connectors.description: To accommodate diverse installation environments, micro gas springs offer multiple end connector options for rapid, reliable integration.

items.application: High-strength applications, precise alignment, or nut-fixed installations.

items.spec: Push-fit into Ø6 hole (no nut required)
items.application: Fast assembly, plastic or thin-sheet structures; greatly simplifies installation.

items.spec: Ø6 mm stainless steel ball / POM socket
items.application: Requires 180° rotation or multi-angle articulation in complex linkages.

applications.title: 5. Typical Applications
applications.description: Leveraging their compact size, lightweight design, and precise thrust characteristics, micro gas springs are extensively deployed in space and weight-sensitive precision equipment.

items.title: Small Inspection Hatches:
items.description: Medical POCT (Point-of-Care Testing) devices, analytical instruments—providing lid support and cushioning.

items.title: Handheld Tool Access Doors:
items.description: Electric torque wrenches, precision measurement instruments—enabling smooth battery cover or service hatch operation.

items.title: Mini Drawer Auto-Eject:
items.description: Cash registers, test fixtures, precision storage cabinets—delivering gentle, automatic drawer extension.

items.title: Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) Payload Doors:
items.description: In weight-critical applications, providing reliable hatch actuation while minimizing payload burden.

faq.title: 6. Customer FAQs & Response Templates
faq.description: Below are the most frequently asked questions during selection and quotation, with professional responses to quickly identify customer needs.

items.question: ① Can you manufacture 8 mm tube diameter?
items.answer: Yes, but with limitations: maximum force is 60 N, stroke ≤ 80 mm; minimum order quantity (MOQ) is 500 units.

items.question: ② Can noise be reduced below 40 dB?
items.answer: Achievable at 30–50 N force range, reaching 38 dB. Requires secondary oil tuning and sample testing on customer equipment for validation.
items.tag: 38 dB requires: force range / oil tuning / field testing

items.question: ③ What is the fastest lead time?
items.answer: Standard forces 30/50/80 N and strokes 60/80/100 mm maintain stock of 1,000 units, enabling 48-hour shipment. Custom configurations require 10 days.

items.question: ④ Can weight be further reduced?
items.answer: Optional full aluminum tube + POM end connector configuration achieves 18% weight reduction at same specifications, though cycle life decreases approximately 20%.

items.question: ⑤ What certifications are available?
items.answer: Standard certifications include RoHS and REACH compliance. Medical-grade ISO 10993 biocompatibility certification requires an additional 7 days.

hero.title:
Push to Lock.
Push to Release.
hero.subtitle: The Self-Locking Gas Spring that simplifies your design. Compress to lock at shortest length, press again to release. No external levers needed.

features.title: Why Engineers Switch to Our Self-Lock Gas Spring

items.title: Built-in Locking Device
items.desc: Increases the locking device on the basis of the standard gas strut. Securely locks when compressed to the shortest position.

items.title: Convenient Operation
items.desc: Unlocking just needs a simple press down. Returns to naturally stretched state automatically. Simpler than levers or buttons.

items.title: Space-Saving Design
items.desc: Does not occupy too much internal space. Ideal for compact applications where external release mechanisms won't fit.

items.title: Reliable Performance
items.desc: Maintains compression state reliably. Suitable for all kinds of situations that need to be locked.

hero.title: What is a Stainless Steel Gas Spring?
hero.subtitle: Engineered for extreme environments. Discover why leading industries switch to SS304 and SS316 for longevity, hygiene, and performance.

intro.title: More Than Just "Shiny" Steel
intro.description1: A Stainless Steel Gas Spring is a premium motion control component made entirely from corrosion-resistant alloys (AISI 304 or 316). Unlike standard steel springs that rely on paint or coating for protection, stainless steel provides inherent, self-healing defense against rust, harsh chemicals, and saltwater.
intro.description2: They are the critical choice where hygiene, aesthetics, and durability are non-negotiable requirements.
checkListItems: Zero Rust: Survives 1000+ hours in salt spray tests (ASTM B117).
Hygienic: Smooth surface prevents bacteria growth; FDA compliant.
Non-Magnetic: Essential for MRI and sensitive electronic environments.

items.label: Molybdenum*
items.note: *Specifically in SS316 for enhanced pitting resistance against chlorides

comparison.title: SS304 vs SS316: Which One Do You Need?
comparison.subtitle: Choosing the right alloy is critical for cost-efficiency and longevity. Here is the definitive breakdown based on high-frequency customer inquiries.

items.title: Marine & Offshore
items.description: Hatches, engine covers, and storage lockers on yachts. Must withstand saltwater mist and humid environments without pitting.

items.title: Food & Beverage
items.description: Production line guards and counterweight assists. Requires FDA-compliant materials and easy wash-down capabilities.

items.title: Medical & Pharma
items.description: Hospital beds, analytical instruments, and clean rooms. Needs sterile surfaces and non-magnetic properties.

questions.q: Can I replace a steel spring with stainless steel?
questions.a: Yes, absolutely. As long as the dimensions (stroke/extended length) and force (Newtons) match, stainless steel springs are dimensionally compatible drop-in replacements for standard steel springs.

questions.q: What is the lead time for custom SS springs?
questions.a: Standard samples can often be shipped in 3-5 days. Custom production runs typically take 2-3 weeks depending on quantity and end-fitting requirements. We maintain stock of common rod/tube sizes to speed up assembly.
Yes. For food and medical applications, we can fill the gas springs with NSF-H1 certified food-grade lubricants to ensure compliance with hygiene standards.

We offer a full range of 316 Stainless Steel end-fittings including eyelets, ball joints, and clevis forks to ensure the entire assembly remains rust-free. Using a steel fitting on a stainless spring would compromise corrosion resistance.

cta.title: Ready to Upgrade?
cta.description: Get a detailed quote for your project within 24 hours. We support low MOQ and custom engineering services.

hero.title: Lockable Gas Spring
hero.subtitle: Rigid locking or elastic soft-rebound — precision positioning you can trust

why.title: What is Adjustable Lockable Gas Spring?
why.subtitle: DKG has a line of adjustable locking gas springs which look like traditional gas springs but can be locked in any position along the stroke. There's an internal locking mechanism that's actuated by a release pin located at the end of the rod. To fit your product requirements, we offer three types of adjustable locking gas springs:

zero.title: Rigid in compression:
zero.desc: No movement when the rod is pushed, but some movement when the rod is pulled.

flexible.title: Rigid in extension:
flexible.desc: No movement when the rod is pulled, but some movement when the rod is pushed.

highLoad.title: High Load Capacity
highLoad.desc: Withstand lateral forces ≥ 2,000 N with reliable locking force plateau performance.

technology.title: Rigid vs. Elastic: The Core Difference

rigid.title: Rigid Locking
rigid.desc: The floating piston separates oil and gas into two chambers. The piston locks in the oil chamber, featuring strong locking force and zero displacement after locking. The nitrogen chamber is small with a high compression ratio.
points: Dual Chamber – Oil-gas separation with floating piston
High Locking Force – ≥ 2,000 N lateral capacity
Best For – Operating tables, tooling fixtures, aircraft bins

elastic.title: Elastic Locking
elastic.desc: There is no floating piston, and only a single chamber exists. The chamber is filled with nitrogen and a small amount of hydraulic oil (for lubrication). It has slightly weaker locking force, minor displacement after locking, and a low compression ratio.
points: Soft Rebound – Allows ≤ 5 mm elastic displacement
Single Chamber – N₂ + lubricating oil mixture
Cushioning Effect – Gentle positioning with damping
Best For – Wheelchairs, hospital beds, office furniture

forcePerformance.title: Locking Force Performance
forcePerformance.desc: The locking force curve shows the stability plateau—the higher and flatter the plateau, the more reliable the locking performance.
forcePerformance.safetyText: Always ensure: Plateau Force ≥ Customer's Maximum Lateral Load × 1.5 Safety Factor

rigid.desc: Rigid Locking: S = working stroke, L = extended length (mm)

elastic.desc: Elastic Locking: S = working stroke, L = extended length (mm)

release.label: Release Mechanism
release.value: ≤ Ø8 mm pin or top button

step1.title: Step 1: Determine Locking Type and Application Needs
step1.description: Rigid and elastic locking are the two main types of gas springs and the key starting point for selection.

rigid.label: Rigid Locking
rigid.title: Rigid Locking Characteristics
items: Minimal displacement under pull force in locked state (typically ≤ 2mm)
Ideal for precise positioning and absolute support
Applications: Medical beds, auxiliary instruments, precision equipment

elastic.label: Elastic Locking
elastic.title: Elastic Locking Characteristics
items: Significant displacement under force in locked state (> 1mm)
Applications: Office chairs, leisure beds, comfort-focused equipment

step2.title: Step 2: Determine Stroke and Installation Space
step2.description: Use formulas to determine the relationship between stroke and extended length based on space and movement range.

rigid.title: Rigid Locking Formulas
rigid.minLen: Given Stroke S, find minimum Extended Length:
rigid.maxStroke: Given Extended Length L, find maximum Stroke:

elastic.title: Elastic Locking Formulas
elastic.minLen: Given Stroke S, find minimum Extended Length:
elastic.maxStroke: Given Extended Length L, find maximum Stroke:

dimensionRule.label: Dimension Rules:
dimensionRule.text: The ratio of cylinder diameter (D) to piston rod diameter (d) should not be less than 1.1. Standard series: KQ10/22, KQ10/28. Contact us for custom needs.

step3.title: Step 3: Force Calculation
step3.description: Force design is central to ensuring smooth load bearing and reliable locking.
subDesc: Use n springs? Divide F by n.
For lockable springs, you also need to consider the locking force and friction, which might require specialized configurators.
Complexity: Real-world applications involve changing geometry and dynamic forces;

nominal.title: Nominal Force (Fₙ)
nominal.description: The initial force during extension or compression. For Fₙ > 100N, use increments of 50N.

support.title: Support Force (Fₛ)
support.description: Ensure support force < 1.3 × Fₙ (max air pressure) for smooth lifting.

locking.title: Locking Force (Fₗ)
locking.description: Compression locking force for rigid gas springs should exceed:

opening.title: Opening Force (Fₒ)
opening.description: The force required to release the lock, typically determined by user needs.

step4.title: Step 4: Performance Verification
step4.description: Confirm the product meets the following technical requirements during selection.

metrics.title: Cycle Life
metrics.value: DKG gas springs reach 50,000 cycles with < 12% force decay.

metrics.title: Sealing Performance
metrics.value: No stroke change after 24 hours under rated force at any angle.

metrics.title: Environmental Adaptability
metrics.value: Must meet temp requirements (-30℃ to +60℃) and corrosion resistance.

step5.title: Step 5: Final Model Selection (Model Output)
step5.description: Record and purchase selected specifications in the following format.

example.label: Example:
example.text: KQ 10/27 60 260 F350 indicates 10mm rod, 27mm cylinder, 60mm stroke, 260mm extended length, and 350N force.

manufacturing.title: Precision Manufacturing Process
manufacturing.desc: Every lockable gas spring undergoes rigorous quality control with specialized precision assembly steps.

difference.title: Key Difference
difference.desc: Compared to standard gas springs, lockable versions include a critical precision assembly step for the floating piston, needle valve, and steel ball locking mechanism.

qa.title: Quality Assurance
qa.desc: Force characteristic testing, pressure retention verification, and 10,000-cycle leakage testing ensure long-term reliability and performance.

items.title: Long Lead Times
items.desc: We reduce delivery from 8–12 weeks to 2–4 weeks as a direct replacement for Stabilus, Suspa, and Hahn products.

items.title: Micro-Movement After Locking
items.desc: Switch to our Rigid Series (KQ10-28 Rigid) for zero-displacement performance.

items.title: Release Mechanism Mismatch
items.desc: We offer full customization for ≤ Ø8 mm side pins or top buttons to fit your existing structure.

items.title: Missing Technical Drawings
items.desc: We provide sample measurement + CAD + 3D PDF within 48 hours.

items.title: Incomplete Certifications
items.desc: We deliver TS16949, ISO9001, RoHS, 96-hour salt spray, and SGS reports—all in one package.

items.question: What makes marine gas springs different from standard gas springs?
items.answer: Marine gas springs use 316L stainless steel construction and specialized seals to resist corrosion from salt water and harsh marine environments. They're also designed to meet Zölle erledigt for marine applications.

items.question: How do I calculate the force needed for my marine application?
items.answer: Force calculation depends on the weight of the hatch/cover, mounting geometry, and desired opening effort. Our engineers provide free consultation to determine the optimal force for your specific application.

items.question: What's the typical lifespan of marine gas springs?
items.answer: Our marine gas springs are designed for 100,000+ cycles and typically last 10-15 years in normal marine use. We offer a 30-year warranty on materials and workmanship.

items.question: Can you provide custom mounting brackets?
items.answer: Yes, we offer custom mounting brackets and hardware designed specifically for marine applications. All brackets are made from marine-grade materials with proper corrosion protection.

items.question: Do you ship to all US states?
items.answer: Yes, we ship to all 50 states with standard 10 days delivery. Express and same-day delivery options are available for urgent marine applications.

items.question: What certifications do your marine gas springs have?
items.answer: Our marine gas springs meet ABYC standards and are ISO 9001:2015 certified. We also provide CE marking for international compliance when needed.

whatIsGS.title: What is a gas spring?
description: **Gas springs** are hydro-pneumatic energy storage components. They consist of a precision piston rod moving within a sealed cylinder filled with pressurized nitrogen and oil.
No matter the position of the gas spring, the pressure around the piston is consistently uniform, due to the rod’s small cross-sectional area.This why gas spring perform steady than coil spring.
The spring force **(F)** is calculated as the pressure differential **(ΔP)** between the internal and external environments acting on the piston rod cross-sectional area **(A): ( F = ΔP / times A)**.
Specifications can be tailored by adjusting nitrogen injected, oil quantity, and piston rod area to meet specific application requirements.
In high-pressure environments, the pressure difference **ΔP** must be carefully managed.
Following introduce different types of gas spring.

howGSWork.title: How Gas Springs Work?
desc: Gas springs—also known as gas struts or gas dampers—work by using compressed nitrogen gas as an elastic energy storage material within a sealed metal cylinder. The cylinder also contains a small amount of hydraulic oil (such as lubricating or damping oil). These oils serve three main functions:
Support the gas sealed within the cylinder.
Lubricate moving parts to reduce wear.
Provide damping.

When you push the piston rod into the cylinder (this is the **compression** process), the space available for the nitrogen gas gets smaller. Just like squeezing a balloon makes the pressure inside go up, this smaller volume causes the gas pressure inside the cylinder to rise—this follows [Boyle’s Law](https://www.britannica.com/science/Boyles-law).

The force the gas spring puts out gets stronger as you push the rod in, and it’s strongest when the rod is fully pressed into the cylinder. This more steady, reliable force than coil spring, is why gas springs are used in everyday things like car tailgates (to hold them open gently), industrial machines (to control movement), and ergonomic furniture (like adjustable office chairs).

KeyBehavior.title: Gas Spring Force Curve
desc: If you look at the diagram above, you’ll see how the gas spring acts as the piston moves.

With gas springs, force increases exponentially as they are compressed, requiring less initial force to compress them. As the gas spring nears the end of its stroke, the compression force needed rises.
** Piston Extended State **
When the piston is fully extended, the cylinder has the most space for gas.
** Piston Compressed State **

As the piston moves to fully compressed, the gas space shrinks—so the pressure goes up (you can see this on the solid line in the diagram). The dashed line shows how the cylinder volume decreases at the same time.
imageCaption: **F1** = extension force with extended piston rod.
**F2** = extension force with compressed piston rod.
**F3** = pull-in force with extended piston rod.
**F4** = pull-in force with compressed piston rod.

CriticalPerformanceMeasure.title: A Critical Performance Measure: The K-Factor
frontdesc: The extension force is calculated by multiplying the filling pressure by the piston rod’s cross-sectional area. Size as well as force can be made according to your requirements.
DK standard gas springs offer extension forces from **10 N to 5000N,**  with tolerance is ± 5-7%.
The specified force (F₁) is always measured at **20°C ± 2°C**, with the piston rod facing downward.
Physically, the actual force of a gas spring depends on the temperature. For each 10°C, the force changes by approx 3,3%.
desc: To define how well a gas spring works, engineers use something called the K-factor (or **gas spring progression rate**). Put simply, this is the percentage change in force between two states:
Unloaded: When the piston is at P1 (fully extended, the spring’s **starting position**).
Fully loaded: When the piston is at P2 (fully compressed).

Good quality gas springs have a very low K-factor—usually between 1.05 and 1.8. For comparison, mechanical compression springs (like the coil ones we mentioned earlier) have much higher K-factors. A low K-factor means the spring’s force stays steady as it compresses—this is important for applications where you need consistent lifting or damping (like holding a heavy car tailgate at any angle).

One quick note for calculations: Gas springs are pre-charged to a specific force at P1 (we call this force F1)—so you should always use F1 as your starting point when figuring out the right gas spring for a job.

Replacement.title: How to Choose a Gas Spring: Replacement by Code and Size?
Replacement.subTitle: Replacement, according to code and size(key: EL2 / stroke / pressure)
desc: **Stroke of a Gas Spring:** This indicates the maximum range of motion of the rod, ranging from its fully retracted point to its fully extended point.
**EL1: Extended or Expanded Length:** This term denotes the total length of the gas spring, measured from the midpoint of one end fitting to the midpoint of the opposite end fitting.
**EL2:** If no end fittings are specified, it pertains to the length from the rod end to the tube end.

howChooseGS.title: How to Choose a Gas Spring: A Simple Guide for Engineers
howChooseGS.description: You, as an engineer, have a certain problem which has to do with controlled movement and needs to be solved without extra engergy? Follow questions to get your selection done.We can assist you in selecting the proper gas spring for your application—and also can help with the design!
howChooseGS.imageNote: Note: We will receive your input and get back to you within **12hours**.

howItWork.title: Here’s how it works:
list: 1. **Simple Sketch** – Provide a basic drawing (like the example on the top) showing:
The weight of the moving part
All dimensions (measured from the pivot/hinge point)
2. **We Handle the Rest!** – Send us your sketch, and we’ll recommend the best gas spring for your needs.
It’s that easy! **Just share your requirements**, and we’ll take care of the rest.

table: Determination of minimum extension force F1
L=Distance between the center of gravity to the Center of gyration(Unit:mm)
b=Effective force arm when the gas spring extends(Unit:mm)
P=Mounting position on the gas spring door, namely about 1/3L away from the center of gyration.

EFC.title: Extension Force Calculation
desc: The extension force is calculated by multiplying the filling pressure by the piston rod’s cross-sectional area. By adjusting these factors, DK can produce gas springs with a wide range of extension forces to meet your needs.

These values can be influenced, e.g.by the gas volume or the oil quantity. A special characteristic of DK gas springs is the low friction figure.Through the combinations of different nozzle orifices and oil quantity, its possible to control the push-out and pushin speed as required.

GSInstallationGuide.title: Gas spring : Selection of Installation Location
desc: 1. The piston rod **must be installed in a downward orientation** (never inverted). This minimizes friction and ensures optimal damping and cushioning performance.

2. Correct fulcrum positioning is critical: When the associated component (e.g., a door) is closed, the gas spring’s movement must pass beyond the structural centerline. This prevents unintended automatic resetting (e.g., the spring pushing the component open).
3. Adjust joint orientation by rotating the cylinder or piston rod clockwise.
4. Ensure proper dimensions and force rating. For example, in hood applications, the piston rod should retain ~10 mm of stroke when closed.
5. Operate within the ambient temperature range: -30℃ to +80℃.
6. Gas springs are high-pressure components—**never disassemble, heat, bake, or strike them**.
7. Avoid tilting/lateral forces during operation; do not use as handrails.
swinging. Misalignment may cause jamming or noise.
8. To protect seals and extend lifespan:
Avoid damaging the piston rod surface.
Do not apply paint/chemicals to the piston rod.
Do not pre-install the spring before welding, grinding, or painting.
GSInstallationGuide.imageCaption: Note: Gas spring installation location orientation.
